titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Winthrop J.V. Osterhout papers, Rockefeller University Faculty FA186

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-08-05 00:32:23 -0400.

change.item: Paper finding aid converted to EAD/XML by AureXus in 2010. Imported into the Archvistsâ€™ Toolkit by Becky Robbins.

did.unittitle: Winthrop J. V. Osterhout papers, Rockefeller University Faculty

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Osterhout, W. J. V. (Winthrop John Van Leuven)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Winthrop John Vanleuven Osterhout, physiologist, succeeded Jacques Loeb as head of the Division of General Physiology at The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research in 1925. His influence upon students, colleagues, and the biological audience in general was exerted toward quantitative data and mathematical analysis of biological processes. He was an editor of The Journal of General Physiology for 45 years, beginning with its founding in 1919.

eventgrp.event: University of Bonn (student with Eduard Strasburger)
Instructor in Botany; University of California
Member Board of Scientific Directors Rockefeller Institute
Member, Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research
Died April 9 in New York, NY. Ashes buried in cemetery of St. James the Less, Philadelphia, Pa.
Trustee Marine Biological Lab., Wood's Hole, Mass.
Co-Editor The Journal of General Physiology

bioghist.p: Member of: A.A.A.S. Fellow, National Academy of Sciences of America, American Philosophical Society, Botanical Society of America, American Society of Naturalists, Academy of Arts and Sciences, NY Academy of Sciences, Botanical Society, Edinburgh, American Physiological Society, Society of Experimental Biology & Medicine, American Chemical Society, Century Club, Kungliga Fysiog. Sallskapet, Lund, Leopold-Carolin Deutsche Akademie der Naturforscher (Halle).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is restricted pending permission from Rockefeller University.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The Osterhout papers which consist of about 750 items are at the American Philosophical Society. An inventory of these papers are in box 1.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Box 1 received or inventoried: September, 1974. Box 2 and Box 3 added to collection May 1980 form the Office of Faculty Records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence 1933-1940 with copies of correspondence 1924 on his appointment as Member of RIMR. Correspondence deals with retirement provisions and allowance for widow.
Includes reprint from "The Development of Harvard University" 1869-1929, Chapter xxii: Botany; Biographical memoir. National Academy of Sciences, v. (1947)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Probably made by Marian Irwin Osterhout. Dealing with published works and first mentions of important developments contributed by W.J.V. Osterhout.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bibliography, photograph; Half a Hundred Radcliffe Women.
Several manuscripts which may not have been published.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 28 letters between Marian Irwin (later Marian Irwin Osterhout) Simon Flexner and Edric Smith. The letters consist, primarily of administrative matters but includes letter of resignation 27 March 1933. The letters of Marian Osterhout are all handwritten.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists primarily of administrative correspondence between Dr. Osterhout, Simon Flexner, and Business Manager. When Dr. Osterhout lost his sight the correspondence was carried on for him by his wife, Marian Irwin Osterhout.

1 folder in Box 2 contains one photograph, reprint of "Physiological studies of single plant cells" from BIOLOGICAL REVIEWS 4 (1931) ; an outline of the history of The JOURNAL OF GENERAL PHYSIOLOGY; duplicate copies of WHO'S WHO information; 3 1939-1939 news clippings; copy of minute adopted by Board of Scientific Directors in 1939; bibliography 1925-1956; obituary from BROWN ALUMNI MONTHLY.

relatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: The Osterhout papers which consist of about 750 items are at the American Philosophical Society. An inventory of these papers is in Box 1.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Added to the collection May 1980, from the Office of Faculty records.

did.unittitle: Letter concerning the naming of Tryparsamide

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (while a Member of the Board of Scientific Directors, December, 1919-1923)

did.unittitle: Correspondence at the time of Jacques Loeb's death

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: February 11: arrangements regarding the editorship of JGP and later an invitation to become member of RIMR scientific staff.

did.unittitle: January 1, 1926 resignation from Board of Scientific Directors

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes closing of Bermuda Station and February 28 marriage to Marian Irwin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes 1961 reconsideration of pension provisions and additional annuity for Mrs. O at Dr. O's death
